## 1. How deterrence is measured

| Concept | What it means in research | Typical data source |
|---------|---------------------------|---------------------|
| **General deterrence** | The effect of a penalty on the *overall* crime rate in a jurisdiction (e.g., state, country) | Aggregate homicide statistics, execution/ imprisonment rates |

| **Marginal deterrence** | Whether a *more severe* sanction (death vs. life) reduces the *marginal* incentive to commit a crime | Econometric models that compare jurisdictions with different maximum penalties, while holding other factors constant |

Researchers typically use **regression analysis**, **difference‑in‑differences**, or **synthetic‑control** methods to isolate the effect of the death penalty from other variables (economic conditions, policing, gun laws, etc.).  The rarity of executions makes statistical power a chronic problem.

A few isolated studies claim a modest “special deterrent” effect for the death penalty, but those findings rest on methodological choices that are widely disputed and have not withstood replication. ## 1. What “certainty of punishment” means in the research literature  

| Term (often used in papers) | Operational definition | Typical data source |
|-----------------------------|------------------------|---------------------|
| **Probability of apprehension** (sometimes called “detection certainty”) | Share of homicides that result in an arrest or a police “clearance” | FBI Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) “clearance‑by‑arrest” rates; local police agency reports |
| **Probability of conviction** | Share of arrests that end in a conviction (or a guilty plea) | State court‑level conviction statistics; National Corrections Reporting Program |
| **Probability of a severe sanction** (e.g., life‑without‑parole) | Share of convictions that receive a sentence of life‑without‑parole (LWOP) or death | State sentencing databases, Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) “Sentencing Project” tables |

Researchers treat these probabilities as the *certainty* component of the classic deterrence equation:

\[
\text{Expected Cost} = \text{Probability of detection} \times \text{Probability of conviction} \times \text{Severity of sanction}
\]

When the expected cost rises because the **probability** term rises, most empirical work finds a measurable drop in homicide (or other violent‑crime) rates.
